string.text: Alright, Dushman's just sent me a beep. I assume that means he's given you the intel. I've settled down in an area the locals refer to as Jupiter. Get there alive, I'll send you our precise coordinates soon.
Good luck down there, guys.
Soldiers, Jupiter Underground is now secure and under control. Send the coordinates to your squad members, and wait for new orders.
I knew I shouldn't trust you.
$name speaking. I stashed some supplies for emergency situations in $location. Here are the coordinates, be sure the message reaches troopers in need.

Hope you guys are doing fine on your missions. I want to inform our troopers about a stash I hid in $location. You'll find some supplies and whatnot. Hope one of you'll make good use of them. $name out.
Uh... this is $name. I made my way into $location. Goddamn mutants everywhere... Anyway, I left a stash here for future visits just in case. Here're the coordinates if you're ever up shit creek.
Soldier?
So, we made it after all. What's next, commander?

We were lucky to break past the Ukrainian military's perimeter undetected. All other UNISG spec ops units have also successfully broken into the Zone, and are settling at the agreed checkpoints as planned. While the rest of the squad is going to rendevous with them, I'll need you for a special task. Go see a man known as "Dushman". He's the main liaison between the mercs and their outside clients. Any questions?
For what reason am I seeing this "Dushman"?

Intel. The mercs have been here a long time, and have drawn up maps and notes that'll be very useful to us. It's vital we obtain that knowledge, as it'll help reduce the risk of long-term expeditions deep into the Zone, as well as tell us where we stand the best chance of finding what we came for.
And he'll just hand over all that intel?
Pretty much, yeah. The UN has already sent a king's ransom for the information. Go see him, and he'll be more than happy to pass on a copy of what he knows about the Zone.
Couldn't he have sent us this information digitally?

The mercs like to sell their information for as much as possible. Any information sent through a network becomes easier to steal or copy. Information that is easier to steal or copy sells for less. As you might've gathered, they don't really care much about making things easy for us, and we don't really have a lot of choice.
Will I be able to find you here if I need you for anything?
No, the rest of the squad needs to keep moving. Once you retrieve the intel from Dushman, I'll give you our new location, along with further orders.
Why are we working in such small groups?

For now, it is imperative that we don't attract too much attention. It is easier to get by without suspicion when travelling in smaller squads. I shouldn't have to say that it'd be an operational and political clusterfuck if the Ukrainian government learns of our spec ops units. However, even if they discover us, our spread out, cloak-and-dagger style will make us hard to pin down entirely, which'd buy us enough time to salvage the mission should things go pear-shaped.
What is our stance toward the locals?

They're aware of our officially sanctioned units researching the Zone, although they mustn't know about our secret mission. Many of them would try to rob us, attack us, or at least report us because of "ideological differences" anyway, and we must ensure our special task remains a secret. If anyone other than a mercenary spots you, they must be eliminated. No witnesses.
You think the locals would report us to the SSU?

Exactly, even if it's only indirectly. Between common stalkers working for information brokers, Ecologists sending reports to their government overseers, and factions like Duty blabbing to Spetsnaz, there are eyes and ears everywhere. If even one of them reveals that UNISG is scouring areas that are officially off-limits, our entire operation is put at risk.
And how will I travel through the more populated areas? Surely mass murder will also attract unwanted attention?

Mortality rate in the Zone is extremely high, and many stalkers disappear without a trace daily. However, you've got a point. It's probably a good idea to obtain some sort of disguise, so you can pretend to be a local when passing through major stalker camps. Although risky on its own, it's certainly far more practical.
How do we know that Dushman and his mercs are trustworthy?

The UN's relationship with the mercs has never been clear-cut. However, not only have we paid them a king's ransom for the information, but they've been promised an even greater sum if our operation goes well. We've bought their silence, effectively, and it's currently in their best interests to see us succeed. That said, I wouldn't be surprised if they turn on us the second we fuck up, so watch yourself out there.
What is our overall operational goal?

UNISG's task is twofold: firstly, there are bona fide scientific teams conducting general research on the Zone. Secondly, there are special forces teams intended to raid the old labs for documentation that could shed more light on the Zone's true nature. We suspect it may be man-made, and if we can confirm this, we'll be able to justify deeper and more open investigation. You and I are part of the second group.
What else can you tell me about UNISG's operation in the Zone?

From what I heard, this isn't the first international operation in the Zone. Our predecessor group, known simply as "ISG", used to be fairly active. They were environmental researchers sponsored by the UN, as opposed to the Ecologists, who operate under orders from the Ukrainian government. However, they had to disband shortly after the Second Emission in September 2011, owing to immense casualties.
And what happened after ISG disbanded?

There weren't too many survivors, but most opted to leave the Zone. Some, however, chose to sign up with mercs or Ecologists, or just strike it out on their own as Freedomers or free stalkers. \nSome members valiantly carried on with their original mission, but their numbers continued to dwindle. In short, it seemed that the eyes and ears of the UN in the Zone were forced shut for good.
Yet here we are.

Indeed. A few ISG diehards kept making quiet appeals to the UN for support over the years, although they were mostly ignored. That changed recently after a massive emission was seen all the way from London. Any surviving ex-ISG we could identify either got put to work as spies within their new factions, or were recalled from the Zone by the UN to form the scientific core of UNISG. My boys and I are just soldiers though, as are most of UNISG operatives nowadays, come to think of it.
It sounds like the old ISG is quite different from the new one.

The old one consisted mostly of scientists, and they were operating with the full blessing and permission of Ukraine. However, with that permission came oversight, interference, censorship. We have reason to suspect that the full truth of the Zone was being kept from our old researchers, to the potential detriment of the entire world! This time, we're coming in with our own resources, our own guards. The UN has provided all our funds, so that we can uncover the full truth for ourselves this time.
No more questions, Commander. I'm ready to go.

Good lad. When you see Dushman, be sure to give him the code phrase for the information: "Still remember blue ocean in this dying world." \nI will mark his location on your PDA, and the way to get there.
Is that a Firelake lyric?
...yes. Now go.
Ciao.
Major Hernandez has sent me to retrieve some intel from you.
Right. What's the passphrase?
"Still remember blue ocean in this dying world".
Let's hope it never has to be just a memory. Here's all the information that UN requested.
Thank you.

Before you go, I know the pay for government work can be pretty shitty. If you ever want to make some real cash, and you're able to be discreet, feel free to pop down here - we mercenaries always have plenty of work that needs doing. Very lucrative, corporate-paid work.
I'll keep that in mind.
Good. Wouldn't want you to feel like you're trapped in your current job. Not everyone's comfortable about dying for some politician's bullshit. Why work for them when you can work for yourself?
This operation is bigger than all of us, Dushman. If we cross paths again, hopefully it'll be for the right reasons.
So, you offered me a job. I'm interested.

Glad to hear. An employer wants some serious job done. Not even I could tell you exactly who, what or where they are. Only that they've got money, and a lot of it. Regardless, this employer has asked we perform favours for a list of "interested parties". Your PDA will be updated with their details as relevant. Stay frosty and watch your back out there. The Zone may be immensely lucrative, but it's also a living hell, and nothing I've seen so far has convinced me otherwise.
Ah, you're not dead. Good.
Ah, you're not dead. Good.
I also have the intel.

Even better. As you can see, we've found a good shelter here, but it's still too exposed. We'd like to explore the catacombs below and see if it's habitable, but the last squad that we sent dropped out of contact and hasn't returned since. This is my fault for being too hasty. Before we send anyone else, we'll need to scour the factory just up the hill for anything that might give us clues as to the layout of the catacombs below.
What makes you think we'll find anything useful in that factory above us?

As you can see, we have an extra squad with us now. When we found them, they reported they'd been investigating the Jupiter Factory, and found a sealed briefcase full of documents, floor plans, building layouts and the like. \nThey had to make a quick retreat, however, to avoid being spotted by an unexpected military platoon. The briefcase was left behind, and must be recovered.
How shall we approach the factory?
Carefully. Reports indicate there may be a platoon of Ukrainian troops skulking about up there. They must be eliminated as quickly and as quietly as possible.
I'm ready to help search the factory.

Good lad. Take a squad under your command. Recover the documents and eliminate any witnesses who happen to be in that building when you arrive. In the meantime, I'll look over the intel you brought from Dushman. Dismissed.
Aye, sir.
Here's the briefcase. All present witnesses were eliminated.

Okay, let's take a look-see...hmm - ah! Here it is. "Pripyat Underpass", also known to the locals as "Jupiter Underground". The layout seems simple enough. However, according to Dushman's documents, it also looks like exactly the sort of environment that mutants would love. Dark, dank, a little cramped in places. Hm. Now we know why our last squad didn't return from there. Still, the layout also indicates there are some big, cavernous areas down there too... And according to the requisitions manifest between the factory and the underpass, there're some documents down there that were supposed to have been evacuated in 1986, and again in 2006... but both times they never made it out. Interesting, isn't it?
What's the plan, sir?

We scour the place together, find the documents that were left behind, and then set ourselves up in one of the more spacious areas. I can't imagine we'd be getting many visitors down there, so it'll be perfect for us. Are you ready to go down now?
Alright, let's get going.

Good lad. We'll all go together. Watch each other's back, make sure you know where your buddy is at all times. Some of you may have encountered mutants already, but I heard the underground ones are a whole different kind of nasty. So buckle up, shake your heads clear, and stay frosty. You can take point.
Yes, sir.
Wait, I need a moment to catch my breath.
Okay, but the longer we stay topside, the more likely it is we'll get discovered.
I'm ready to secure the underground.

Good lad. We'll all go together. Watch each other's back, make sure you know where your buddy is at all times. Some of you may have encountered mutants already, but I heard the underground ones are a whole different kind of nasty. So buckle up, shake your heads clear, and stay frosty. You can take point.
Yes, sir.
Sir. These must be the documents mentioned in the manifest.

This... this is incredible. This alone could help the UN make its case to escalate an open and public investigation into the Zone of Exclusion. But we need to find more. The evidence must be insurmountable. I'll contact the remaining itinerant UNISG squads and let them know we've established a strong central base for them to work from. Nothing better than being right under Pripyat, aye?
Guess we're almost ready to step out of the shadows?

Not yet, but soon. There's still more preparation to be done. I might've mentioned that part of the reason we're here is to locate and search the old labs scattered across the Zone. Thanks to the information you brought from Dushman, that is now possible. His notes mention that many of these labs have already been searched. However, documents that had already been recovered had since mysteriously disappeared; probably the SSU plugging their leaks. The notes also mention that very few who enter the labs ever come out, and that - as such - it's highly likely they still contain plenty of the evidence we're looking for. Considering what we found in this underpass alone, it sounds like a bet we should certainly take.
What kind of evidence are we looking for?

Literally any document you find within those labs, you grab. Leave no stone unturned. It's possible that many of the Zone's phenomena originated because of the research happening in those labs. In other words, it's possible that this freak accident of an ecological disaster is, in fact, the result of deliberately engineered, Geneva Convention-violating weapons of mass destruction. We need anything that can help prove that. \nIdeally, we want to leave this hellhole with an overwhelming amount of evidence that the contents of the Zone could pose a very real international security risk. A risk too big for some East European backwater to handle. \nThis will pressure Ukraine into letting the UN have free reign over Chernobyl and its secrets... maybe even shift the national monopoly of the artefact trade into new hands...
That sounds pretty slimy.
Slimy or not, this is our job, and we shall see it through.
I agree. The Zone could threaten the entire world. Its containment shouldn't be under the full control of only one state.
I'm glad you agree.
What do you think the UN actually cares about: protecting the public or usurping the artefact trade?
It's not my place to comment. Nor is it yours.
Who shall we send to investigate these labs?

I think you will be our best candidate. You've proven yourself competent not only in combat, but also in handling the locals and surviving on independent tasks. All without alerting the SSU. Before you go, however, take this.
What is this?
One of our spies from within the Ecologists has managed to send us schematics for a...eh...a "psy-protection device".
What, like from mind control?

Precisely. I swear, the more you learn about this place, the shittier it looks. In any case, this helmet we built should protect you from whatever "mind control" devices happen to still be active within the labs.
Holy shit. This is turning into some horror-film stuff.

You'll be alright. I've outfitted some of our men with similar devices, so you can take them with you if you like. Anyway, remember: your task is to recover any top secret documents from the labs, and leave no witnesses. Let me mark the locations on your PDA. Here.
I will not fail you, sir.
Yes, your top info courier has returned yet again. Take a look at these.
Impressive... Well done! You've earned a commendation from me. The UN will be pleased to discover what we have now learned.
Anything interesting happened while I was away?

Several other UNISG squads have also returned from their own expeditions to the NPP and beyond. Between their efforts and yours, I think we've got a pretty good idea of what's been happening behind the Zone's scenes for the past few decades. However, there are still some unexplained mysteries. If the Zone's creators have since disappeared or perished, how is it that it has only strengthened? Likewise, how is it that the fanatical cult known as the "Monolith" have managed to stay so strong and well supplied for all these years?
Do you know where we might find answers to these mysteries?

Yes. Remember that military group we encountered in the Jupiter factory? Turns out they weren't there by accident. They were trying to accomplish the same thing we were, only they'd rather burn the documents than let the world know about them.
And you have discovered the location of another squad?
Yes. Not only that, but my spies have also deduced their goal: this military squad is chasing down their former Chief Scientific Consultant.
That sounds a little odd. Why would they do that?

Their Chief Consultant earned his position not through a doctorate, but rather through his immense first-hand experience with the phenomena of the Zone. Apparently, he uncovered many of its secrets, including details of its origins that are still missing from our own notes. If half of the stories about his deeds are true, I'm hardly surprised. In any case, he clearly wasn't satisfied with his official post, considering he fled back here. Can't imagine what kind of job makes a person want to take a holiday in this sort of hellhole.
And who is this man?
They call him... Strelok.
Do you want me to retrieve him for you?

Yes. He's the final piece of the puzzle. Save him from the military forces pursuing him on the outskirts of Pripyat. Convince him to help us. If he testifies for the UN against the Ukrainian government's handling of the Zone, it'll make proceedings that much easier.
And if he refuses to help?

Then extract his knowledge any way you can, and return with it. I can assign you a squad to provide assistance if you think things will go that way. From what I know, he might actually be more dangerous than the soldiers pursuing him.
I'm not taking any chances. Sir, please let the squad know they'll be leaving with me shortly. We'll find Strelok, take care of his pursuers, and subdue him before he knows what's going on.
I'll go alone. I'm confident Strelok will help us out once I help him, and don't want to risk him getting hit by friendly fire.
Very well. Good luck.
About Strelok, sir...
I see that look in your eyes. You killed him. What happened?
He refused to surrender. There was little other choice. However, I found this flashdrive on him. Maybe it containts something of worth.
You just led one of the most knowledgeable, cunning and dangerous men in the ENTIRE ZONE into our field HQ without disarming him. Explain yourself.
It was the best way to get the drop on him, not to mention hide the evidence of his passing. You might want to take a look at what he was carrying.
I was beginning to think you'd been captured by the enemy. What took you so long?
I agreed to help Strelok. In return, he gave me this flashdrive. It contains a lot of information about the Zone's history... and its mysteries.
Hm... Let's see... \nUnbelivable... This is more than we could've hoped for...
What do you see in there, sir?

Top secret documents, info about the laboratories, complex devices, personal experience and observations about the CNPP, the Wish Granter... Strelok not only went through it all, but kept his experiences well documented too. I call this mission accomplished. Great job, soldier!
Have we succeeded, then? What happens now?

It's time for us to leave this hell and return home. The UN will be happy with our results. I'll let all the UNISG squad commanders know that it is time for them to withdraw from the Zone, for now. Same as before, small groups.
Understood.
Some of our science teams will remain to study the artefacts and anomalous fields. Some of our soldiers have also chosen to sign on with the mercs, so they can stay longer.
Is that allowed?

I have given them leave, yes. They've shown a desire to... integrate... into the Zone's unique brand of life. I can trust them to keep their secrets, and the connections they make will come in handy later on. \nWell, we've got what we came for. Your role in this operation is complete. If you were to also choose to stay in the Zone, you have my blessing, although doing so would possibly mean missing out on some juicy promotion opportunities. Think it over. \nDismissed.
Uh... I lost my way. I need to leave this place.
Hm. I will ask someone from my squad to pick you up. Which way you want to go?
Back to our previous hideout, under Jupiter Factory.
To the outskirts of Pripyat.
Nevermind, I will go by myself.
Very well.
Very well.
Hey, don't I know you?
Yeah, you do seem a little familiar... hang on. Yeah, I know you too! No way! Dude, how'd you make Captain already?
I don't have an official rank for this operation, I'm just answering directly to the Major.
Guess he has really special plans for you then. If you were any more of a snowflake, you'd melt.
And what about you? You're a Lieutenant now.
Hell yeah! I'm proud of it, too. Can't say it's what I imagined when I first set my sights on becoming an engineer, but I'd say things worked out pretty damn well!
You're extremely happy for a man stuck in an irradiated hellhole.
One hellhole is as good as any other, isn't it? At least the gun monkeys around here are too drunk to shoot straight half the time. Hehe...
Speaking of shooting straight...

Ah, right. Should've known you weren't here for my dashing charm and good looks. If your shooter got a little dusty, or even if it IS nothing but dust, hand it to me and I'll make it run smoother than an oil slick on ice.
What are you planning to do now the mission is over?
Uh, leave with everyone else? What, you aren't thinking of going native, are you?
Nah. I'd much rather return home and see my family again. It'd be nice.
Of course not. I'll be leaving with the rest of UNISG. Maybe you and I will see each other around sometime.
Not really, but I feel I must stay in the Zone. Regardless of what the Major thinks, I don't believe my work is done here.
Now that the operation is over, I'll likely strike out on my own. Maybe make a name for myself amongst the mercs. Have to say, I'm looking forward to it.
Ah, alrighty then. Whatever floats your boat.
Sounds like a plan, I guess. Look, if you get in trouble, I never knew about this, alright?
Hey, Maus. I need someone to guide me to the new hideout...
The tushkanos gave you nightmares down there, heh? Don't worry buddy. I will contact one of the guys to pick you up.
That was a close one. Who are you?
I represent the United Nations. Strelok, we need you to come into our custody and testify for us against the Ukrainian government.
The Zone's got a truly twisted sense of humour. Rescued from a team of government goons by another another government goon. I'm hardly thrilled.
I've proven myself to be more than a match for them. Surrender, or else.
I refuse.

There's no need for any more deaths. I've come alone to assure your safety, and learn what you know. It could help the world start a serious investigation into the Zone. And it'd be under international management: no more government lies or secrets about this place.
Why would I trust a word you say?
Because it'd mean you'd cease to be hounded or harassed in any way by the Ukrainian military for the rest of your life.

That does sound good. But I can't have the UN breathing down my neck all the time while I sit in some gilded cage, either. If you get me out of this place, I can share some of the Zone's secrets with you.
Fair enough. Where do you want to go?
The Red Forest. That place is a death zone, but I know my way around there. That'll discourage further military pursuit.
Alright, your knowledge of the Zone in return for your safety. Let's go.
Here we go, Strelok. You're safe now.
You're a man of your word. Thank you.
And now for your word, Strelok.

Of course. Here, my personal flashdrive. It contains documentation of all my experiences and thoughts regarding the Zone, along with copies of the many interesting papers and other information I found during my travels. The UN will find all the answers they need, but know this: the Zone isn't and will never be easy to understand. We're like cavemen who scraped two stones together and accidentally kindled a blaze. We aren't sure what happened and what we are looking at. Meanwhile, the fire's spreading, consuming everything around it...
Thank you. This is possibly more than I could've hoped for. I'll return to my commander. What about you?

I've got some old friends to bury, and one to visit. After a while, you really begin to realise what a precious commodity time is, and how important it is to remember the moments you've already spent...
Goodbye, Strelok.
Shit. After all this, I'm not sure I can bring this information back to my commander.
Interesting. Second thoughts?

Maybe. I know what I said earlier, but the more I think about it, the less I believe the UN will use this information for good. What you've shared with me could change the entire world. It shouldn't be left in the hands of people who already hold all the power. \nI need to stick around and learn more about the Zone myself. I need to learn more before I can be sure what the right choice is. And I cannot do that unless I become my own stalker.
I understand that feeling more than you could possibly know.
I might get caught and court-martialed for desertion in the end. Ironically, it'd be because of the other documents I found earlier. They might allow the UNISG to invade the Zone in force some day.

I'm also very sceptical of the ability of any government to handle this situation. But that won't be an issue if the documents you have already collected won't leave the Zone. In fact, I could use my contacts among stalkers to tip off the military, so they could tighten security and prevent your comrades from escaping the perimeter. It can be done.
Well, thanks, but I don't want my... former comrades to be hurt.

Maybe there is another way. We'll see. In the meantime, if you really intend to follow through on this, I suggest visiting Rostok or Zaton. There's always some work there for a free stalker, and a place to blend in or hide. Who knows, you might even be able to make some friends there. \nAnyway, we're running out of time. Let's get going.
Will I ever see you again?

Probably not. I need to bury some old friends, say hello to the ones who are still alive, and then probably find some place to disappear to. I think I've found my answers. Hopefully, you'll find yours. You can keep my flashdrive. I won't be needing it any more.
Goodbye, Strelok. Perhaps I'll meet you one day at a roadside picnic.
